name: Takamine Jokichi
summary: Takamine Jokichi was a Japanese-American chemist who isolated adrenaline (epinephrine) in 1901, the first hormone to be isolated in pure form. He also developed Takadiastase, a starch-digesting enzyme used in medicine and industry. His work bridged Japanese and American pharmaceutical science.
timeline: Established Japanese garden in New York

name: Kitasato Shibasaburo
summary: Kitasato Shibasaburo was a pioneering Japanese bacteriologist who co-discovered the bubonic plague bacillus and developed antitoxin serotherapy. He was the first to isolate the tetanus bacillus in pure culture and demonstrated that antitoxin could provide immunity. He founded the Kitasato Institute and is considered the father of Japanese bacteriology.
timeline: Studied under Robert Koch in Berlin
Isolated Clostridium tetani in pure culture
Co-developed serum therapy with Emil von Behring

name: Noguchi Hideyo
summary: Noguchi Hideyo was a prominent Japanese bacteriologist who made important contributions to the study of syphilis, yellow fever, and other infectious diseases. Working at the Rockefeller Institute in New York, he demonstrated the syphilis spirochete in the brains of paresis patients. He died of yellow fever while researching the disease in West Africa.
timeline: Graduated from medical school in Tokyo
Found Treponema pallidum in paresis brains
Researched yellow fever and other tropical diseases
Went to West Africa to study yellow fever
Died of yellow fever in Accra, Gold Coast

name: Yukawa Hideki
summary: Yukawa Hideki was a Japanese theoretical physicist who predicted the existence of mesons in 1935, explaining the strong nuclear force that holds protons and neutrons together. He received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1949, becoming the first Japanese Nobel laureate. His work was foundational for nuclear and particle physics.
timeline: Published meson theory of nuclear forces
Became director of RIMS, Kyoto University

name: Tomonaga Shin'ichiro
summary: Tomonaga Shin'ichiro was a Japanese physicist who independently developed the theory of quantum electrodynamics (QED), for which he shared the 1965 Nobel Prize in Physics with Richard Feynman and Julian Schwinger. His renormalization approach resolved the infinity problems in quantum field theory and established Japan as a center for theoretical physics.
timeline: Studied under Werner Heisenberg in Leipzig
Became professor at Tokyo University of Education
Served as president of Tokyo University of Education

name: Honda Kotaro
summary: Honda Kotaro was a Japanese metallurgist and physicist who made significant contributions to the science of steel and magnetic materials. He developed KS steel, a powerful magnetic steel alloy, and founded the Research Institute for Iron, Steel and Other Metals at Tohoku University. His work laid foundations for Japan's modern steel and materials industries.
timeline: Founded Research Institute for Iron, Steel and Other Metals

name: Yamanashi Yoshio
summary: Yamanashi Yoshio was a Japanese electronics engineer who made pioneering contributions to the development of fiber optic communications in Japan. His research helped establish Japan as a world leader in optical fiber technology. He also worked on semiconductor laser technology essential for telecommunications.

name: Nishina Yoshio
summary: Nishina Yoshio was the father of modern physics in Japan. He studied under Niels Bohr in Copenhagen and derived the Klein-Nishina formula for Compton scattering. He established Japan's first cyclotron and led Japan's wartime nuclear research. After the war, he helped rebuild Japanese physics research.
timeline: Went to Europe to study physics
Derived Klein-Nishina formula with Oskar Klein

name: Esaki Leo
summary: Esaki Leo (Esaki Reona) is a Japanese physicist who discovered quantum tunneling in semiconductor junctions, leading to the invention of the tunnel diode (Esaki diode). He shared the 1973 Nobel Prize in Physics for this discovery. His work was foundational for modern semiconductor electronics and quantum devices.
timeline: Joined IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center
Returned to Japan as president of Tsukuba University
Received Grand Cordon of the Order of Culture

name: Suzuki Umetaro
summary: Suzuki Umetaro was a Japanese chemist who isolated the first vitamin (thiamine/vitamin B1) from rice bran in 1910, publishing his findings as aberic acid (Oryzanin). He published his discovery before Casimir Funk, but his paper was in Japanese and lacked the claim of a new nutrient class, so he did not receive full credit internationally.
timeline: Studied in Berlin under Emil Fischer
Isolated thiamine (vitamin B1) from rice bran
Casimir Funk coined 'vitamine' for similar compound

name: Ikeda Kikunae
summary: Ikeda Kikunae was a Japanese chemist who discovered umami as a fundamental taste and isolated monosodium glutamate (MSG) from kombu seaweed in 1908. His discovery of the fifth basic taste revolutionized food science and led to the founding of the Ajinomoto company. He was a professor at Tokyo Imperial University.
timeline: Studied in Leipzig under Wilhelm Ostwald
Began researching the taste of kombu dashi
Isolated glutamic acid as source of umami taste
Became full professor at Tokyo Imperial University

name: Tanaka Koichi
summary: Tanaka Koichi is a Japanese engineer who won the 2002 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing soft laser desorption ionization (SLI) for mass spectrometric analysis of biological macromolecules. Working at Shimadzu Corporation as a salaryman engineer, he was one of the most unexpected Nobel laureates, having no PhD degree.
timeline: Published key paper on protein mass spectrometry
Named person of cultural merit by Japanese government

name: Yamanaka Shinya
summary: Yamanaka Shinya is a Japanese stem cell researcher who won the 2012 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering that mature cells can be reprogrammed into pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs). His four transcription factors (Yamanaka factors) revolutionized regenerative medicine and eliminated many ethical issues surrounding embryonic stem cells.
timeline: Graduated from Kobe University Medical School
Earned PhD from Osaka City University
Joined Nara Institute of Science and Technology
Generated first induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs)
Became director of CiRA, Kyoto University
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Akasaki Isamu
summary: Akasaki Isamu was a Japanese engineer and physicist who invented the efficient blue light-emitting diode (LED), enabling white LED lighting. He shared the 2014 Nobel Prize in Physics with Hiroshi Amano and Shuji Nakamura. His decades-long persistence in gallium nitride research transformed global energy-efficient lighting.
timeline: Created first GaN p-n junction blue LED
Achieved bright blue LED with InGaN

name: Amano Hiroshi
summary: Amano Hiroshi is a Japanese physicist and engineer who contributed to the development of the efficient blue LED. Working with Isamu Akasaki, he grew high-quality gallium nitride crystals using a novel buffer layer technique and achieved p-type GaN doping. He shared the 2014 Nobel Prize in Physics.
timeline: Grew high-quality GaN using AlN buffer layer
Achieved p-type GaN doping by electron irradiation
Created efficient GaN blue LED with Akasaki

name: Nakamura Shuji
summary: Nakamura Shuji is a Japanese-American engineer who independently developed practical high-brightness blue LEDs and blue laser diodes using InGaN technology while working at Nichia Corporation. He shared the 2014 Nobel Prize in Physics. His work enabled white LED lighting and Blu-ray disc technology, and he later won a landmark lawsuit over inventor compensation.
timeline: Left Nichia, joined UC Santa Barbara

name: Kato Jokichi
summary: Kato Jokichi was a Japanese chemical engineer who developed synthetic ammonia production methods and contributed to Japan's chemical industry. He advanced fertilizer manufacturing technology and helped establish Japan's modern chemical engineering infrastructure during the early 20th century.
timeline: Contributed to postwar chemical industry rebuilding

name: Sato Katsumoto
summary: Sato Katsumoto was a Japanese plant pathologist who studied rice blast disease and developed disease-resistant rice varieties. His research on fungal pathogens of rice significantly improved Japanese and Asian rice production. He trained many plant pathologists across East Asia.
timeline: Identified key rice blast pathogen mechanisms

name: Tanabe Hajime
summary: Tanabe Hajime was a Japanese mathematician and philosopher who contributed to the development of mathematical logic and philosophy of science in Japan. He studied under Husserl in Germany and established the Kyoto School's mathematical-philosophical tradition. His work on dialectical logic influenced Japanese scientific thought.
timeline: Became professor at Kyoto Imperial University

name: Nagata Takeshi
summary: Nagata Takeshi was a Japanese geophysicist who made pioneering contributions to the study of rock magnetism and paleomagnetism. His discovery of self-reversal of thermoremanent magnetization was crucial for understanding geomagnetic field reversals. He also led Japanese Antarctic research expeditions.
timeline: Published major work on rock magnetism
Became director of National Institute of Polar Research

name: Makino Tomitaro
summary: Makino Tomitaro was Japan's greatest botanist, known as the 'father of Japanese botany.' A self-taught genius, he named and classified over 1,500 new plant species and varieties. He published the Makino Illustrated Flora of Japan, the definitive reference for Japanese plant taxonomy. Despite poverty and lack of formal education, his contributions were immense.
timeline: Entered botany department at Tokyo University as assistant
Named hundreds of new plant species
Published Makino Illustrated Flora of Japan

name: Minakata Kumagusu
summary: Minakata Kumagusu was a polymath Japanese naturalist and biologist who discovered numerous new species of slime molds and contributed to ecology, ethnology, and folklore studies. Self-educated, he studied at the British Museum and corresponded with leading scientists worldwide. He was a passionate environmentalist who fought to preserve Japan's old-growth forests.
timeline: Traveled to the United States for study
Studied at the British Museum, London
Led campaign to save Nachi shrine forest

name: Kimura Hisashi
summary: Kimura Hisashi was a Japanese astronomer who discovered the Z-term in latitude variation, an unexplained annual component of polar motion. His discovery, known as the Kimura term, was a significant contribution to geodesy and geophysics. He directed the International Latitude Observatory of Mizusawa for over 40 years.
timeline: Became director of Mizusawa Latitude Observatory
Discovered the Z-term in latitude variation

name: Yagi Hidetsugu
summary: Yagi Hidetsugu was a Japanese electrical engineer who co-invented the Yagi-Uda antenna with his student Shintaro Uda. This directional antenna became the most widely used antenna design in the world, used in television reception, radar, and communications. Ironically, Japan did not initially appreciate the invention, while Allied forces used it extensively in WWII.
timeline: Studied in London, Dresden, and Berlin
Published Yagi-Uda antenna with Shintaro Uda
Became president of Osaka Imperial University
Became president of Tokyo Institute of Technology

name: Uda Shintaro
summary: Uda Shintaro was a Japanese electrical engineer who designed and built the first Yagi-Uda antenna in 1926 while working under Yagi Hidetsugu at Tohoku University. While the antenna bears both names, Uda did much of the practical design work. His antenna became the most common directional antenna worldwide.
timeline: Designed and built first Yagi-Uda antenna
Received Order of the Rising Sun

name: Takagi Teiji
summary: Takagi Teiji was a Japanese mathematician who founded class field theory, one of the most important achievements in algebraic number theory. His proof of the Takagi existence theorem generalized the work of Hilbert and Kronecker. He was the first mathematician to bring Japanese mathematics to the forefront of world research.
timeline: Studied under David Hilbert in Göttingen
Published proof of class field theory

name: Nishizawa Jun-ichi
summary: Nishizawa Jun-ichi was a Japanese semiconductor engineer known as the 'father of fiber optics and semiconductor lasers.' He invented the PIN diode, static induction transistor, and semiconductor laser for fiber optic communications. He held over 200 patents and was instrumental in Japan's semiconductor and telecommunications revolution.

name: Omura Satoshi
summary: Omura Satoshi is a Japanese microbiologist and chemist who won the 2015 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering avermectin, which led to the anti-parasitic drug ivermectin. His systematic screening of soil microorganisms for bioactive compounds has saved hundreds of millions of people from river blindness and lymphatic filariasis.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Tokyo
Ivermectin developed by Merck from his discovery
Merck donated ivermectin for tropical disease treatment
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Shimomura Osamu
summary: Shimomura Osamu was a Japanese organic chemist who discovered green fluorescent protein (GFP) and its companion protein aequorin in the jellyfish Aequorea victoria. He shared the 2008 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for GFP, which revolutionized biological research by enabling scientists to visualize proteins and cellular processes in living organisms.
timeline: Isolated aequorin and GFP from jellyfish at Princeton
Joined Boston University Marine Biological Laboratory
GFP began widespread use in biology

name: Kamihara Hideo
summary: Kamihara Hideo is a Japanese physicist who discovered iron-based superconductors in 2008, the first new class of high-temperature superconductors since the cuprate superconductors discovered in 1986. His discovery of superconductivity in LaOFeAs opened a new field of condensed matter physics research worldwide.
timeline: Began research on iron pnictide compounds
Iron-based superconductors Tc raised above 55K by others
Continued research on new superconducting materials

name: Akira Endo
summary: Akira Endo was a Japanese biochemist who discovered the first statin drug, mevastatin (compactin), which led to the development of cholesterol-lowering medications that have saved millions of lives. His discovery that certain fungi produce compounds that inhibit cholesterol synthesis was one of the greatest pharmaceutical breakthroughs of the 20th century.
timeline: Studied at Albert Einstein College of Medicine
Published findings on HMG-CoA reductase inhibition

name: Moriguchi Shigekazu
summary: Moriguchi Shigekazu was a Japanese pioneer of computer science who led the development of FUJIC, Japan's first electronic computer, in 1956. He also contributed to the development of early Japanese programming languages and numerical computing methods. His work launched Japan's computer industry.
timeline: Completed FUJIC, Japan's first electronic computer

name: Toyoda Sakichi
summary: Toyoda Sakichi was a Japanese inventor and industrialist known as the 'King of Japanese Inventors.' He developed numerous improvements to the power loom, including the automatic loom with non-stop shuttle change. His Toyoda Automatic Loom Works later became Toyota Motor Corporation. His invention philosophy inspired the Toyota Production System.
timeline: Sold automatic loom patents to Platt Brothers (UK)

name: Nagai Nagayoshi
summary: Nagai Nagayoshi was a Japanese chemist who first synthesized methamphetamine in 1893 and isolated ephedrine from Ephedra sinica in 1885. He studied under August Wilhelm von Hofmann in Berlin and became one of Japan's first modern pharmaceutical chemists. He established the foundations of Japanese pharmaceutical science.
timeline: Went to Germany to study chemistry

name: Hatoyama Hideo
summary: Hatoyama Hideo was a pioneering Japanese civil engineer who designed many of Japan's first modern bridges and infrastructure during the Meiji period. He introduced Western engineering techniques to Japan and helped establish civil engineering as a professional discipline. His bridges remain landmarks of Japan's modernization.
timeline: Began designing modern bridges in Japan
Built major bridges using Western techniques
Became leading civil engineer in Japan

name: Ito Yoji
summary: Ito Yoji was a Japanese marine biologist who made significant contributions to fisheries science and aquaculture technology. His research on fish breeding, nutrition, and disease control advanced Japan's aquaculture industry, making it one of the most productive in the world. He developed improved techniques for farming yellowtail and sea bream.
timeline: Contributed to Japan's aquaculture industry growth

name: Kihara Hitoshi
summary: Kihara Hitoshi was a Japanese geneticist and cytologist who discovered the genome analysis method for determining wheat phylogeny. He identified that bread wheat is a hexaploid with three ancestral genomes (AABBDD) and traced the evolutionary history of wheat species. His work was foundational for modern cereal crop genetics and breeding.
timeline: Identified D-genome donor of bread wheat
Continued genetic research at Kyoto University

name: Miyake Setsuya
summary: Miyake Setsuya was a Japanese geochemist who pioneered marine geochemistry research in Japan. He studied the chemical composition of seawater, marine sediments, and atmospheric-ocean interactions. His research on radioactive fallout in the Pacific Ocean after nuclear tests provided crucial data for understanding oceanic circulation.
timeline: Studied radioactive fallout in Pacific Ocean
Published major works on ocean geochemistry

name: Noyori Ryoji
summary: Noyori Ryoji is a Japanese chemist who won the 2001 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his work on chirally catalyzed hydrogenation reactions. He developed BINAP-based asymmetric catalysis, enabling the efficient production of single-enantiomer drugs and chemicals. His methods revolutionized pharmaceutical manufacturing.
timeline: Applied asymmetric catalysis to pharmaceutical synthesis

name: Toshiba Tanaka Hisashige
summary: Tanaka Hisashige was a Japanese inventor and engineer known as the 'Thomas Edison of Japan.' He created remarkable mechanical dolls (karakuri), the perpetual clock (mannen-dokei), and Japan's first domestically produced steam engine. He founded the company that would become Toshiba Corporation. His inventions demonstrated extraordinary mechanical genius.
timeline: Created Japan's first steam locomotive model

name: Miura Koryo
summary: Miura Koryo is a Japanese astrophysicist and structural engineer who invented the Miura fold, a rigid origami folding pattern used in space solar panel deployment. This ingenious folding method allows large flat surfaces to be compactly folded and deployed with a single pull. It has been used in satellite solar arrays and has applications in engineering and mathematics.
timeline: Studied structural engineering and space technology
Miura fold used in Japanese Space Flyer Unit
Published mathematical analysis of the fold
Miura fold adopted for various engineering applications

name: Kimura Motoo
summary: Kimura Motoo was a Japanese population geneticist who proposed the neutral theory of molecular evolution in 1968, arguing that most evolutionary changes at the molecular level are caused by random genetic drift rather than natural selection. His theory, initially controversial, became one of the most important concepts in evolutionary biology and molecular genetics.
timeline: Moved to National Institute of Genetics, Mishima
Earned PhD from University of Wisconsin
Proposed neutral theory of molecular evolution
Published mathematical foundations of neutral theory
Published 'The Neutral Theory of Molecular Evolution'

name: Hashimoto Hakaru
summary: Hashimoto Hakaru was a Japanese physician who first described the autoimmune thyroid condition now known as Hashimoto's thyroiditis in 1912. His detailed histological observations identified the lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland. This was one of the first autoimmune diseases to be recognized, though the autoimmune mechanism was not understood until decades later.
timeline: Graduated from Kyushu University Medical School
Published description of Hashimoto's thyroiditis in Germany
Returned to Japan to practice surgery
Continued medical practice in Mie Prefecture

name: Seki Takakazu
summary: Seki Takakazu was Japan's greatest mathematician, often called the 'Japanese Newton.' He independently developed many mathematical concepts paralleling Western advances, including determinants (before Leibniz), Bernoulli numbers, and methods for solving equations. He founded the Wasan mathematical tradition and established a school that dominated Japanese mathematics for two centuries.
timeline: Published solutions to problems from Kokon Sanpoki
Published Kai Fukudai no Ho (method of solving equations)

name: Tanakadate Aikitsu
summary: Tanakadate Aikitsu was a Japanese physicist who pioneered geomagnetic surveys and seismological research in Japan. He conducted the first comprehensive magnetic survey of Japan and advocated for the romanization of Japanese. He was a key figure in establishing modern physics research in Japan and mentored many Japanese physicists.
timeline: Studied under Lord Kelvin in Glasgow

name: Tokuda Shusei
summary: Tokuda Shusei was a Japanese seismologist who advanced earthquake prediction research and developed improved methods for seismic analysis. His work on understanding the mechanisms of deep earthquakes and plate tectonics contributed to Japan's world-leading earthquake preparedness systems.
timeline: Advanced plate tectonics studies in Japan

name: Wada Yenzo
summary: Wada Yenzo was a Japanese mathematician and astronomer of the late Edo period who made significant contributions to wasan mathematics. He developed methods for calculating pi to unprecedented accuracy and advanced techniques in infinite series. His mathematical works extended the tradition founded by Seki Takakazu.
